Recollections of Personal Experiences
In Connection With
Yellow Fever Epidemics in Havana
1898 - 1899 - 1900
------------------
(Dictated by Request)

Our Secretary, Mr. McLelland, has asked me to
place on record the recital I gave at a recent meeting
of our Board of Directors of episodes connected with
Walter Reed and his investigations and discoveries with
reference to yellow fever.

1 In November, 1898, after we had taken Santiago
and peace had been made, a Peace Commission, of which
General Wade was President for the United States and
General Blanco for the Spanish Government, was formed
for the purpose of arranging the details of transfer of
the governmental authority from the Spanish Crown to the
United States Government. During the sittings of this
Commission, which commenced in August, an epidemic of
yellow fever broke out in Havana. Colonel Williams, of
the United States Army, and Colonel Waring, head of the
Sanitary Department of New York City, had been ordered
to Havana to make preliminary provisions of transfer,
respectively, of everything pertaining to the Quarter-
master's Department and to sanitation.

2 In November these two officers, together with
a large number of their clerical force, died of yellow
fever. I was ordered to Havana to take over the office
of Colonel Williams and another officer was ordered
there to take up the work of Colonel Waring. The second
officer did not arrive, so when I reached Havana in
November I found myself at the head of the Quartermaster's
Department, under the orders of General Charles F. Humphrey,
and in charge of the Sanitary Department, which had been
undertaken by Colonel Waring. The latter activities I
transferred to Major Gorgas, of the Medical Corps, who
later was made Surgeon General of the Army, in the fol-
lowing year, but I continued with the Quartermaster's
Department until the final withdrawal of our troops on
the twentieth of May, 1902.

3 There was much sickness at this period and
great anxiety on account of the prevalence of yellow
fever. Colonel Williams and Colonel Waring had occupied
an office jointly next door to the Passaje Hotel on the
Prado. Practically all the clerks of both these offices
5-
Mrs. Peterson was north at time her
husband was taken ill & hastened
back arriving just the day of his death
She shot herself not for fear of y. f-
but because she did not wish to live
without him-
- 2 -
met me on my arrival, with a resignation in one hand
and a request for transportation back to the United
States in the other. Of the few who remained, notably
Sergeant Merzig and Mr. Curry, I proceeded to build a
new organization for both services.

4 As the colder weather came on, the yellow
fever conditions decreased in intensity and did not
reappear again in epidemic form until two years later,
in 1900. In that year, symptoms of the epidemic ap-
peared in Havana and various outlying centers, notably
Pinar del Rio, Guanajai, Vedado, Quemados and various
military stations. At this time I had become the Chief
Quartermaster of the Department of Cuba -- General
Humphrey, my predecessor, having been ordered to duty
in China. I occupied for my office the building then
known as the Segundo Cabo, facing the Plaza on which
was located the Governor General's Palace. In this
same building were located the offices of Chief Pay-
master and Chief Commissary. In a vacant room on the
second floor of this building we organized a small
mess, where we served our luncheons. There were eight
people who were members of this mess, including my
principal assistant, Major George Cartwright, Major
Matt Peterson, Chief Commissary Officer, Mrs. Peterson,
his wife, Captain Page, and aide-de-camp to the Command-
ing General, Colonel Dodge, the Chief Paymaster,
Lieutenant Hanna, an aide-de-camp to the Commanding
General, Lieutenant E. C. Brooks, an aide-de-camp to
the Commanding General, General Wood.

5 The earliest deaths from yellow fever during
this epidemic occurred outside the limits of Havana,
at Pinar del Rio and Marianao. The first of this group
at mess to go down with yellow fever was Major
George Cartwright, my principal assistant, who died
of the disease. Sitting at his left was Major Peterson,
who went down with the disease and died. Mrs. Peterson
was ill at the time and when she was told by Major Gorgas
that he feared she had contracted the disease, she pro-
duced a pistol from her bag and shot herself. On the
next day, as I followed this double funeral to the
last resting place, a carriage ahead of me turned out
and I paused long enough to speak with the occupant,
Captain Page, who informed me that he was so ill he
could not proceed. I told him I would go on to the
funeral and as soon as I got back would get in touch
with him. Page occupied quarters at the top story of
Segundo Cabo. When I returned to my office I found
him there, unable to climb the stairs to his quarters,
and with help I assisted him to his room at the top of
- 3 -
the building. Within forty-eight hours he died of
yellow fever. The next to be stricken with the
disease was Colonel Dodge, Chief Paymaster of the
Department. Fortunately, he recovered and later
became Paymaster General of the Army. The next place
at the table was vacant as Lieutenant Hanna had taken
a leave of absence, returned to the United States, and
later resigned his commission in the Army. That left
Captain E. C. Brooks and me looking across the corner
of the table at one another.

6 At the advice of the surgeons, we had been
in the habit of serving a small quantity of red wine
at luncheon. Someone of the group, at the early
inception of the epidemic, had proposed the old English
toast: “To those who are gone already and here's to
the next to go”. This toast was drunk daily until Brooks
and I were left looking across the corner of the table
at one another. Then, when he poured out a glass of
wine, and pushed the decanter to me, he lifted his
glass and gave the toast. I remember saying; “Brooks,
I won't drink that toast to myself. You had yellow
fever in Santiago and are immune and won't have it
again. Besides that, you are a teetotaler and don't
drink. So I'll drink my wine, but not the toast”. He
laughed and neither he nor I was stricken with the
disease.

7 During this same period, one after the other
I placed five men in charge of Major Cartwright's
papers, which I was anxious should be closed up as
promptly as possible, especially in view of the condi-
tions that existed. In order to make sure that they
would be promptly closed and worked upon continuously,
I set aside a small room back of my own office and
assigned a clerk to this special duty. The first that
I placed in charge was Mr. Ferguson, a civilian clerk,
supposed to be immune, having passed through more than
one epidemic in New Orleans. Within twenty-four hours
after he took charge of the papers he came to me and
said he was too ill to go on. The next day he was
dead of yellow fever. One after the other, five men
working on these papers went down with yellow fever.
The fifth man went down but fortunately recovered and
finished the papers.

8 About this time Major Gorgas came to me and
asked me to take his yellow fever ambulance (one that
he had been using to haul yellow fever patients) into
the shops and overhaul it. He assured me that there
could not possibly be any contamination connected
Dr. Carlos Finlay was a British subjects
from in Cuba of English parents-
- 4 -
with the ambulance and it could not possibly communi-
cate the disease. I explained to Gorgas that I would
be very glad to take the ambulance in and put it
through the shops, and had no misgivings in regard
to the communication of the disease, but I feared for
the morale of the men working on the ambulance if
they knew it was an ambulance used to carry yellow
fever patients. “Well”, he said, “we'll try not to
let them know that that is the case”, and he suggested
that he leave the ambulance out in the weather and I
could pick it up and take it into my establishment
and send him another ambulance to take the place of
it temporarily. This I did. The result was that
one after the other, the wheelwright, the blacksmith,
the finisher, the painter, and the superintendent of
shops all went down with yellow fever, and all died.

9 In the meantime, Major Reed, at the head
of the Board that has made him his greatest fame,
and all members of which became famous, came to
Havana for the purpose of investigating the source
and possible prevention of the disease. In my
capacity of Chief Quartermaster I set up his office,
furnished it for him, furnished him transportation,
and built the small buildings in which he carried
out his investigations and experiments. I was in
constant contact with him. I had already known
him when he came to the Seventh Army Corps to make
the study of the typhoid epidemic, when he headed
the Board known as the Reed-Vaughn-Shakespeare
Board, and whose report is known to medical men
throughout the world for its scientific determina-
tion of the means by which that disease is carried.

10 Dr. Carlos Finley, an American physician
who had lived and practiced in Havana for many
years, had advanced the theory that yellow fever
was carried by the mosquito, but he had never been
able to prove it. Major Reed at once proceeded to
investigate this theory, with the result that by
the end of the year 1900 he had conclusively shown,
together with the other members of his Board con-
sisting of Majors Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte,
that the mosquito was the guilty party in the dis-
semination of this dread disease. The methods by
which he arrived at this conclusion are well known
to the medical profession and the details of the
small buildings which he used in determining this,
are also well known.

in 1882

11 Each one was divided into threetwo compartments.
Dr. Finlay had concluded that only
the house mosquitos (Stegomyia now
Called Aedes egypti) was the vector
& he gave Reed some eggs of this
mosquito in a little dish
Only one experiment was tried
with any other mosquito
- 5 -
The subject would enter the first compartment after
having all mosquitoes carefully driven away, remove
his clothing, enter the next compartment and clothe
himself in sleeping garments, and from there he would
enter his sleeping apartment where he remained during
the period of the experiment. In order to test the
possibility of the communication of this disease by
direct contact or contamination, the garments and
bedding in which patients had died of the disease
were placed in the sleeping compartment of one of
these buildings. In no case was yellow fever con-
tracted by this means.

12 In order to satisfy the Board, infected
mosquitoes were bottled up and after the subject
had entered his sleeping compartment were permitted
to bite him. In some instances yellow fever resulted,
in others there was no result. By continued experiment
it was found that only a certain breed of mosquito
communicated the disease and eventually it was dis-
covered that only the female of that breed was guilty.
With further experimentation it was found that even
she was not always capable of transmitting the disease.
To make the transmission effective, it was necessary
that the mosquito bite a patient suffering from the
malady and at a particular stage of development, and
in communicating it, it was necessary that the mosquito
bite the victim at a certain time (about five days)
after having bitten an infected person. The result
of this was that after less than six months of
experimentation, Walter Reed was able to publish
his findings, to the effect that the disease is
carried by nothing else but the mosquito, and one
breed of mosquito, and only the female of that
breed, at a certain stage after having bitten a
yellow fever patient.

13 Both Dr. Lazear and Major Carroll submitted
themselves to this test. Lazear, as everyone knows,
was so unfortunate as to die in this experiment.
Carroll recovered but was never an entirely well man
afterward. Practically all members of the Hospital
Corps on duty at that time at Camp Columbia in Marianao
most heroically submitted themselves for this test.
Fortunately, none of these men died. It was my
pleasure, not long ago, to witness the placing of
medals on the breasts of two of the survivors, after
a period of something more than thirty years after
the occurrence.

14 Major Reed became very much interested in

mosquitos breeds & lives about
human habitations only
- 6 -
my personal experience in connection with the disease
and was rather curious as to why I had not been taken
down with the disease, having been constantly living
in the same conditions that so many others had lived
and had been stricken---in the mess and in my office
and in the corral. It could easily be understood that
the mosquito was the guilty party, but it could not be
understood why the mosquitoes would not bite me as
well as all of those others. He asked me about my
medical experience during the period when I had served
in Havana. I told him that I had been taken down with
what the attending surgeon called calentura, and was
in bed for two days, but continued to perform my duties
from my sick-bed. He consulted with the attending
surgeon, Major Laine, and they arrived at the conclusion
that the fever I had had, which had been called calentura,
was in all probability a light case of yellow fever and
had not been discovered, which rendered me immune to the
bites of the mosquito.

15 One of the most interesting features of this
final discovery is to be found in the comparison with
what was actually known of the disease before these
experiments were undertaken. For example, in cases
of epidemic in the United States at various points,
it was found that the disease was curbed by prospec-
tive victims seeking certain localities, usually dry
and free of mosquitoes. In the City of Jacksonville
the entire population moved out into the sand-hills
from the city and established themselves in tents
and temporary quarters. The men would habitually go
in to the city during the daytime to ordinary business,
always returning before nightfall to the sand-hills.
In that way the disease was finally obliterated
without their knowledge of the reason why.

16 As a matter of fact, the yellow fever mos-
quito, as a rule, does not go far away from her
breeding place. She is not active except in a dark
or gloomy corner or room, or after nightfall. Another
incident that had been noted and commented on was
that the disease might start on a street and continue
until it reached a high wall and there it would be
checked until something happened and it would seem to
jump the wall and go on down the street. What hap-
pened was that the winds carried the infected mos-
quitoes over the wall where they continued their
depradations. Another thing, it would go down one
side of the street and leave the other side free
of this dread disease, until all those conditions
would change and it would jump across the street
- 7 -
and go down the other side. This was puzzling, but
after the detection of the culprit it was easily ex-
plained. The winds would come right to carry the
infected mosquitoes over the walls where they would
proceed in their nefarious calling, or the winds
would change and blow them across the street and there
the mosquitoes would start a new center of infection.
All of the phenomena that had been witnessed and com-
mented upon in connection with yellow fever before
Walter Reed's discovery, found a simple explanation
as soon as he had determined that the mosquito was
the culprit. The room in which our group held its
luncheons was infested with mosquitoes which evi-
dently buzzed about in the dark corners, the room
being ill-lighted. The room in which the clerks
worked on Major Cartwright's papers was a dark
room infested with mosquitoes. All of the employees
at the shops slept in the same quarters, which were
found to be infested with mosquitoes. All of the
members of the Reed Board are now dead but they
have left behind them their places in the history
of medical discovery that will remain so long as
the medical profession exists.

17 I wish to add to this recital that it was
of great interest to me to find that General Truby,
now in command of the Army Medical Center, Washington,
D.C., of which Walter Reed Hospital is a part, was a
young officer of the Medical Corps during the entire
period of the first occupation. Truby was the first
medical officer to reach Havana. The Eighth and
Tenth Infantry Regiments were on provost-martial
duty in Havana until August, 1899, when they moved
to Camp Columbia. Reed was a close personal friend
of his and when Reed came to Cuba he and the other
members of the Board, except Agramonte, accepted
the invitation to live with the Medical Staff at
the Hospital at the Camp. It was a great satisfac-
tion, in a recent period of hospitalization, to talk
with General Truby and crystallize my recollections
of the incidents herein related.
